column1: So what did you think about the use of VR in these stories?
I feel like it's beneficial. I feel like it's good in these circumstances.

What parts of these stories stood out to you? The connecting with family, the connecting with the class or learning experiences really felt good. I think they were beneficial. My own boys use VR when they get home from school. They connect with their buddies and their friends. We just moved to Minnesota a while back, so they still connect with folks from Nebraska, where we're from.

They're our friends from there, so that makes me feel good that they still connect with friends back home. And now they're making new friends here in Minnesota, so they're able to connect with new friends here in Minnesota via whatever games they're playing, and I like that.

I think the one video, the last one I watched about the kid logging off for the day, I think they drew his eyes, he's tired because that's probably what would happen. He'd probably feel fatigued in that way. I think as technology progresses, yeah, I think the fatigue won't be there. Maybe we'll find ways to mitigate fatigue. His eyes looked fatigued... day in and day out it could be exhausting

Okay, so that was, yeah, let's talk about some of these maybe problems or issues that might VR create for children. Yeah. So fatigued, yeah? Fatigue, eyesight, maybe impatience. What do you mean by impatience? Impatience is in...

We already deal with them patients a lot with technology, with the phones, or if something's laggy, the Wi-Fi signal, things like that. Or if you have to put something on your head and it's not working properly. It's.

That's kind of where I can see that happening, you know, because I witnessed that. Even though they know I've drilled it into their head, this is very expensive to put in. very scary things to think about, especially with kids.
